paragraphs.text: Boko Haram's deadly advance must be stopped, but how?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Last week's massacre of perhaps 2,000 people in and around the Nigerian town of Baga, and the bombings of markets in the north-east using children perhaps as young as 10, mark not a new tactic for the violent extremist organisation Boko Haram, but an intensification of its existing behaviour
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Boko Haram is pushing the boundaries of the extreme and is challenging - and seemingly succeeding - in overstretching Nigeria's 7th Infantry Division, tasked to fight the insurgents in the north-east
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In recent months it has made significant territorial gains and is in control of many towns around the Borno state capital, Maiduguri
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: though this is in a constant state of flux
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as the military defends state capitals and recaptures lost urban centres
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Speculation as to the aims of Jama'atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda'awati wal-Jihad, the real name of the network of Islamist, cultist and criminal elements that grew from a radical but initially largely non-violent movement, continues
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And the logical conclusion is that it is capturing territory to carve out an Islamic caliphate in north-eastern Nigeria
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the group is decimating what is in its path
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is greedy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the longer Boko Haram goes unimpeded and the more confident it becomes, the more it seems to want
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So perhaps what is its endgame is the wrong question
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Boko Haram is fighting because it can
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because it is a lethal fighting force and has children and conscripts to send into the field as terrified, intoxicated and indoctrinated weapons and shields
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The question that needs to be answered is how did this terrorist threat grow to such horrifying proportions, killing thousands and displacing millions- a threat unimaginable in a democratic Nigeria 10 years ago?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And what can be done to stop it?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nigeria's military is around 130,000-strong, and has been previously lauded for its peacekeeping successes in civil conflicts in Africa
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: now
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: , with a worsening conflict at home, questions are being asked about just how hollowed out such an important institution has become
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are varying reports as to why the 8,500 troops deployed to battle Boko Haram have been unable to halt its advance
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Allegations of corruption; misallocated resources; poorly trained, poorly equipped and poorly directed troops; fear; low morale; and deficient interagency cooperation all have a basis
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While promises have been made to investigate reported abuses by the Nigerian armed forces against civilians, in December 2014 an army court sentenced 54 soldiers to death for mutiny and cowardice - for refusing to fight Boko Haram
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In the short term
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: preventing Boko Haram from expanding further relies on a more effective military response with a much-bolstered force
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But this is impossible without essential leadership from the centre, without tough calls and effective management
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The international community will come under increasing criticism for not doing enough to stem the tide of Boko Haram's terror
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Assistance has been offered by a range of partners including the US, UK, France, Russia and China
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: some of it has been declined
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is likely more offers of assistance will come
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nigeria believes its neighbours Chad, Cameroon and Niger could be doing more
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But domestic and international confidence in the will or capacity - or both - of Nigeria's federal government to take the decisions to mount an effective response is fast waning in the face of increasing casualties
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nigerians will go to the polls on 14 February to vote for a new president and national assembly
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: How much this violence, predominantly in three of Nigeria's 36 states, will affect the outcome is unclear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Nigerians face a range of daily challenges
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are concerns, however, that the majority of people in the states at the epicentre of the conflict - thought to be potential opposition supporters- will be disenfranchised, along with over a million internally displaced people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However politicised the crisis may become in the runup to elections, the insurgency will outlast the event
paragraphs.label: assumption
